DOC.brief_summary: Does caffeine reduce rosuvastatin induced protection against ischemia reperfusion injury?
DOC.brief_title: Does Caffeine Reduce Rosuvastatin-Induced Protection Against Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury?
DOC.detailed_description: Rosuvastatin is a proven cholesterol lowering medicine, which hereby is assumed to achieve a reduction in cardiovascular events. Apart from it's cholesterol lowering action, rosuvastatin may also increase tolerance against ischemia-reperfusion injury. In dogs rosuvastatin increases the endogenous concentration of adenosine, by enhancing the activity of the enzyme ecto-5'-nucleotidase, which converts adenosine monophosphate into adenosine. We hypothesize that rosuvastatin increases tolerance against ischemia-reperfusion injury by induction of ecto-5'-nucleotidase and thereby increasing adenosine activity. This protective effect of rosuvastatin can be abrogated by using the adenosine receptor antagonist caffeine.
DOC.criteria: Male age between 1850 yrs signed informed consent Cardiovascular disease Hypertension (systole > 140 mmHg, diastole > 90 mmHg) Hypercholesterolemia (fasting total cholesterol > 6,0 mmol/l) Drug abuse Concomitant medication use Inability to perform the ischemic isometric muscle contraction Diabetes Mellitus (fasting glucose > 7.0 mmol/L or random glucose > 11.0 mmol/L) AlanineAminoTransferase (ALAT) >90U/L (more than twice the upper level of the normal range) Creatinine Kinase (CK) >340U/L (more than twice the upper level of the normal range) Participation in any trial concerning medicinal products during the last 60 days prior to this study.
